newsitem.title: LATVIA: BRITISH AIRWAYS SEES DAILY RIGA FLIGHTS.
newsitem.headline: BRITISH AIRWAYS SEES DAILY RIGA FLIGHTS.

text.p: British Airways (BA) on Tuesday said that it sees the possibility for daily connections between Latvian capital Riga and London's Gatwick airport soon.
BA started flying to Riga on March 31, the first flights to any of the Baltic states.
"The number of flights may be increased from four a week to a daily service in the not too distant a future," Harvey Lines, Manager Baltic States, told a news conference.
"We hope Riga will be as successful as other new east European destinations, like Kiev and Baku," he said.
BA plans to have 60 passangers per flight on average and in order to balance the incoming passenger flow it is targetting both business and leisure markets, Lines said.
"Riga is featuring as a new alternative to Budapest and Prague for short-term trips on BA Holidays," Lines said.
The departures are geared to flights beyond London, of which there are almost 500 and an average working day.
A special price of $299 both ways is in place until June and an increase of some $20 is expected after that.

The British carrier has agreements in place with Estonian and Lithuanian aviation companies for connecting flights and it is also considering northern Lithuania and Western Estonia to generate passengers.

Three companies, including Latvia's national carrier Air Baltic, part-owned by Scandinavian Airlines fly to London at the moment and BA considers that in medium and long-term the passenger flow through Riga will grow.
"We hope to especially generate more inflying passengers.. We are not only promoting our business, but also Latvia abroad," Lines said.
